Patch Set 15: Code-Review-1

(8 comments)

Abandoned

We discussed among team member and we found the workaround solution in PLDM instead introducing new API in libpldm, so not adding any API now but if we bound in future to add any API then will do in future.
where is this 'persistent file' that you have mentioned hosted? if there is a commit that is using this API you could mention that in the commit message, it would help understand better.
improved commit massage with Gerrit link.
what's the significance of this?
improved function doxygen comment.
next
corrected
Please prefix symbols with `pldm_`. C only has one namespace for its symbols types.
acknowledged.

I'm probably missing some context here, but nothing in libpldm should assume there's any kind of filesystem available. It is used in freestanding contexts such as hostboot and skiboot. Does this now require a filesystem?
acknowledged.
For the BMC to boot properly? Hopefully not?
acknowledged.
Hi Kamalkumar, I've made some comments inline.
See comment about symbol prefix on commit message.
acknowledged.

Is this really necessary? Is there not another way to construct this information? This feels a bit too powerful.

How is this structure extracted?

This function will add initialise empty/new data set which will be used in below gerrit commit and also used for code optimisation for repetitive code which will be taking care for next set of commit.
You mustn't assume the returned pointer is valid. Please handle the error.
acknowledged.

Sorry, but this description is not convincing enough for me to agree to add to the library API surface, especially given the function signature and intent.

At the very least it needs to provide a compelling argument as to why the proposal is the only reasonable course of action possible, by enumerating the alternatives and arguing convincingly why they're not as good.
clarifying commit msg, hope it's enough, if not, we could discuss over discord.
Please trim trailing whitespace
Done
Please don't use tabs after spaces.
Done

The problem I have here is the type is opaque, but the function signature exposes all the members of the opaque type. Why should the type remain opaque when we lose all advantage of keeping it so (any changes would require updating this function signature - and either way it's an ABI break).

Hi andrew,
Agree with you, I tried to use opaque pointer but it won't work, but now i modified initialisation of structure only with pldm entity data which is as per PLDM usecase.
It also support empty structure initialisation for other usecase as well.
Why? What's the motivation?
improved commit message.
Right, but why should there be?
improved commit message.
What is this use case?
improved commit message.

Why this API is the best approach above all other possible approaches (and even enumeration of other possible approaches) is still missing from the description. I don't plan to merge new APIs with mysterious motivations. Can you provide some brief demonstrations how the returned opaque pointer can be used with other, existing libpldm APIs to integrate the entity node into and relate it to other structures?

Also, please try to write your commit messages as regular prose and not a bullet list.

While it's important that we demonstrate there's a user of the proposed API, the justification for its existence must be entirely self-contained in the libpldm commit, either in the commit message or in documentation added in the commit.

Libpldm is allocating memory and pldm is using this node as per pldm storing/restoring node object path into dbus, PLDM is having opaque pointer of 'pldm_entity_node' which can't extracted in PLDM, but it can holds the assigned pldm_entity data. using  pldm_entity pinter which will be null for other usecases and code optimization but for PLDM it will holds the pldm entity values.
improved commit message.
Hi Kamalkumar, I've still got some concerns with the commit message and the API generally. Despite my concerns there, I've also made a comment on the implementation and the test.

Perhaps all this would be better as:

```
    return calloc(1UL, sizeof(struct pldm_entity_node));
```
acknowledge.
I'm not convinced at test that validates a dynamic memory allocation succeeds is beneficial. It doesn't demonstrate anything about the function's behaviour in a production environment.
agree, but since it's opaque pointer so can't extract other values to check in test case.it's gives error when i try to check structure values.
Can you please be more explicit about the relationships? How is the abstraction structured? Adding a mermaid class diagram description into the commit message would be particularly helpful.
Can you list some examples in the commit message of existing APIs that provide this facility?
Needs a space after the full-stop.
Can you please be more specific about what this means in practice? Adding links to examples in the openbmc/pldm code would be particularly helpful.
"Can" and "should" are similar but different. Why should this be the case? Again, can you link to examples of such uses in the commit message?

I'd argue the API you're proposing is the opposite of refined - it is quite powerful with its lack of constraints.

I'm still trying to understand why it's not possible to effectively build up the tree using the existing APIs.

Please demonstrate how here in the commit message. What's the necessary sequence without the new API and why is it ineffective? Contrast this to the sequence that's possible with the new API, and discuss why it's more effective.
Hi Kamalkumar, I'm still trying to ensure I have a complete understanding of the motvations. Thanks for the improvements to the commit message. However, I do have some more discussion points there 😊
